articles.headline: ‘Hero’ Pay Raises Disappear for Many Essential Workers
articles.snippet: Several retailers have ended the pay raises and bonuses they gave to employees as an appreciation for their courage and commitment in showing up to work during the pandemic.
articles.abstract: Several retailers have ended the pay raises and bonuses they gave to employees as an appreciation for their courage and commitment in showing up to work during the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: Many retailers across the United States have quietly stopped providing their workers with the pay raises they had dispensed at the start of the pandemic, despite surging virus numbers in many states.

articles.headline: Three Marines, Now Focus of Russian Bounties Investigation, Show the Costs of an Endless War
articles.snippet: The U.S. mission in Afghanistan is now described as training, advising and assisting Afghan troops. But American forces are still patrolling areas that are as deadly as they were in 2001.
articles.abstract: The U.S. mission in Afghanistan is now described as training, advising and assisting Afghan troops. But American forces are still patrolling areas that are as deadly as they were in 2001.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American military convoy was almost back to Bagram Air Base in Afghanistan when a vehicle, laden with explosives, careened into it and detonated.
articles.byline: By Helene Cooper, Jennifer Steinhauer, Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Judge, Expressing Skepticism, Upends $25 Million Harvey Weinstein Settlement
articles.snippet: The judge questioned whether the women involved in the proposed agreement constituted a legal class. He also said a proposal to pay out $12 million toward legal fees for the producer and his former company directors was “obnoxious.”
articles.abstract: The judge questioned whether the women involved in the proposed agreement constituted a legal class. He also said a proposal to pay out $12 million toward legal fees for the producer and his former company directors was “obnoxious.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Expressing deep skepticism, a federal judge on Tuesday upended a $25 million proposed civil settlement between Harvey Weinstein, his former film company, and dozens of women who have accused him of sexual harassment and abuse.
articles.byline: By Jodi Kantor and Megan Twohey

articles.headline: Banks Stockpile Billions as They Prepare for Things to Get Worse
articles.snippet: JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup and Wells Fargo said that as long as the economy behaved according to their forecasts, they were braced for more pandemic-induced pain.
articles.abstract: JPMorgan Chase, Citigroup and Wells Fargo said that as long as the economy behaved according to their forecasts, they were braced for more pandemic-induced pain.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three of the nation’s biggest banks revealed Tuesday that they had set aside billions of dollars to cover potential losses on loans, signaling that they don’t expect consumers and corporations to be able to pay their debts in the coming months as the pandemic continues to gut employment and commerce.
articles.byline: By Emily Flitter, Stacy Cowley and Gillian Friedman

articles.headline: U.S. Rescinds Plan to Strip Visas From International Students in Online Classes
articles.snippet: The Trump administration said it would no longer require foreign students to attend in-person classes during the coronavirus pandemic in order to remain in the country.
articles.abstract: The Trump administration said it would no longer require foreign students to attend in-person classes during the coronavirus pandemic in order to remain in the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a rare and swift immigration policy reversal, the Trump administration on Tuesday bowed to snowballing opposition from universities, Silicon Valley and 20 states and abandoned a plan to strip international college students of their visas if they did not attend at least some classes in person.
articles.byline: By Miriam Jordan and Anemona Hartocollis

articles.headline: Sessions Pays the Price for Incurring Trump’s Wrath, Losing Alabama Senate Race
articles.snippet: In Maine, Sara Gideon prevailed over limited competition in the Democratic primary for Senate and will face Susan Collins in a race that has become the priciest Senate campaign in the state’s history.
articles.abstract: In Maine, Sara Gideon prevailed over limited competition in the Democratic primary for Senate and will face Susan Collins in a race that has become the priciest Senate campaign in the state’s history.
articles.lead_paragraph: MOBILE, Ala. — As a longtime senator from Alabama, Jeff Sessions did nothing less than legitimize Donald. J. Trump as a credible Republican candidate for president, endorsing him when no other big names did and championing him to conservative voters. As Mr. Trump’s star rose, Mr. Sessions’s rose, too.
articles.byline: By Elaina Plott and Jonathan Martin

articles.headline: A Resurgence of the Virus, and Lockdowns, Threatens Economic Recovery
articles.snippet: Hopes for a rebound are endangered by prolonged closures of schools, renewed state restrictions on business and fears of a difficult autumn and winter.
articles.abstract: Hopes for a rebound are endangered by prolonged closures of schools, renewed state restrictions on business and fears of a difficult autumn and winter.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The United States economy is headed for a tumultuous autumn, with the threat of closed schools, renewed government lockdowns, empty stadiums and an uncertain amount of federal support for businesses and unemployed workers all clouding hopes for a rapid rebound from recession.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Ben Casselman

articles.headline: What Black Lives Matter Has Revealed About Small-Town America
articles.snippet: A multiracial future has appeared, along with unprecedented conversations about race.
articles.abstract: A multiracial future has appeared, along with unprecedented conversations about race.
articles.lead_paragraph: CHAMBERSBURG, Pa. — Nikki Wilkerson was used to thinking of herself as the “small brown girl” growing up in rural Pennsylvania.

articles.headline: Walmart, Nation’s Largest Retailer, Will Require Customers to Wear Masks
articles.snippet: The new rule, which goes into effect on Monday, is a strong statement about wearing masks in public spaces at a time when the issue has become politicized.
articles.abstract: The new rule, which goes into effect on Monday, is a strong statement about wearing masks in public spaces at a time when the issue has become politicized.
articles.lead_paragraph: In perhaps the strongest statement yet by a major American company about the importance of masks, Walmart said it would require that all of its customers wear face coverings starting next week.
